Zain.Action: Stands silently and appears lost in an unsanitary police detention center, unable to respond actively to his situation.
Complies passively with examination and police procedures without resistance or confusion.
Shows bitterness about his imprisonment and openly admits to stabbing someone, revealing raw honesty and straightforwardness.
Expresses desire to sue his parents with a sad look, indicating deep emotional pain and vulnerability.
Greets the pharmacist politely with 'Hello.'
Clearly states he stabbed someone when questioned in court, showing directness and confidence in facing the judge.
Refuses to give his exact age when asked, demonstrating evasiveness or lack of knowledge.
States he lives in Roumieh Prison for Juveniles without hesitation, showing awareness of his situation.
Expresses bitterness and sadness when explaining his motivations, demonstrating emotional expression but not necessarily skill or confidence.
Plans to sue his parents, indicating a calculated and purposeful decision to seek justice or redress.
Claims bitterly to want to sue parents 'because I was born,' showing existential frustration but lacking coherent justification.
Uses a wrinkled prescription and gives multiple excuses to obtain Tramadol from pharmacists.
Quickly changes pharmacies and adapts excuses to get the medicine despite obstacles.
Helps prepare the drugs by mincing them and soaking clothes, showing resourcefulness.
Does not openly challenge the pharmacist's demands or escalate the situation, showing measured responses.
No evident overt leadership or confident communication in other interactions; mostly reactive and subdued.
Waves at his cousin when prompted, engaging politely.
Stands quietly next to Souad while she smokes, appearing lost in his thoughts and sad, showing limited active engagement.
Struggles to unload heavy gallons from a little truck in mid-day heat.
Knocks on a door using his head while holding grocery bags with his hands.
Stands up and unties his little sister’s chained foot, holds her and takes her to another room to stop her crying.
Smells a bloodstain on the mattress, checks whether he injured himself, becomes worried and lost in thought.
Responds with irritation to his little sister’s repeated calls to wake up using harsh language.
No indication of solving the rotten vegetables issue or addressing why Assaad might be upset.
Sings to promote juice, engages in street sales with siblings.
Notices blood on sister's shorts and immediately intervenes.
Drags sister Sahar to public restroom to clean her underwear discreetly.
Warns sister about dangers of Assaad and tries to protect her.
Gives his own t-shirt to his sister to use, showing care and sacrifice.
Squeezes lemon in cups to sell juice, promoting it by singing to attract customers.
Not attentive, sits lost in thoughts while other siblings continue to work.
Notices blood on sister's shorts and promptly moves her to a restroom for cleaning, showing awareness and protective behavior.
Cleans sister's underwear in a dirty public restroom, creatively using his own t-shirt to help her.
Warns sister about danger from Assaad and mother in a vivid, convincing manner to protect her, demonstrating knowledge and concern.
Uses harsh language and fear tactics with sister, which could indicate emotional instability or lack of tact.
Hides a box of sanitary napkins stealthily while sister is distracted.
Instructs Sahar on how to properly hide pads and be careful.
Sings funny Arabic rhymes to promote vegetable juice, engaging customers.
Allows Sahar to eat noodles while walking, and notices her discomfort but does not immediately act to resolve it.
Sings funny rhymes to promote juice sales while his little sister also sells, showing a cooperative family effort.
Offers two pieces of gum to a customer when Sahar sells gum, demonstrating generosity.
Watches over his scared sister Sahar cautiously when a man approaches her, indicating protective and caring behavior.
Hits an older teenager to possibly protect his sister despite the public scene, showing fierce loyalty and protectiveness.
Grabs Sahar’s arm roughly to take her away from danger, indicative of protective instincts but also some possible harshness.
Politely offers to negotiate with Assaad to allow him to both work and go to school, showing responsibility and sincerity.
Sings catchy promotional rhymes to sell juice, actively engages in selling alongside his sister.
Keeps calm and watches over his scared sister Sahar when a man approaches her.
Physically confronts an older teenager in defense of his sister despite possible risks.
Communicates a practical plan to attend school in the morning and work in the afternoon, showing foresight and negotiation skills.
Shows no hesitation when grabbing Sahar's arm and leading her home to protect her.
Mocks Assad behind his back despite Assad being in an annoyed tone towards him.
Struggles while doing hard physical labor delivering gas tanks and groceries in harsh conditions.
Addresses Mrs. Bahia politely and reports completing his work.
Mocks Assad behind his back while receiving instructions.
Struggles to drag the gas tank down the street but completes deliveries.
Fixes the gas tank before handing it over to Bahia, showing initiative to solve a problem.
Drinks rain water out of thirst while walking in heavy rain wearing inadequate clothing.
Allows a veiled woman to help him with heavy grocery bags.
Forcefully removes a man's head who tries to kiss him and angrily tells him to get his hands off.
Shows concern and queries about the chickens and his siblings' activities at home.
Rushes up to see family situation and is angry about Assad's presence and his sister Sahar's behavior.
Angrily threatens and speaks harshly about Assad, telling his mother to tell Assad he has no business there.
Stands up firmly and removes the man’s head when the man, who is high, tries to kiss him, saying 'Get your fucking hands off me!'
Asks clearly and directly about the chickens and their origin in the chaotic stairway environment, showing situational awareness.
Rushes to confront Assad and Abou Assad in the dark room and expresses anger and suspicion about the chickens being traded for his sister Sahar.
Allows himself to be distracted by chaotic and dirty surroundings (e.g., stairway with chickens clucking) without immediately taking control or cleaning up.
Shows aggressive anger and threat ('I'd bet my arm... Tell that sonofabitch he has no business here') rather than calmly managing family conflict.
Removes lipstick from Sahar's face, calls her 'witch' but shows underlying sadness.
Threatens to kick out the children after juice, insists on confronting Assad.
Signals the little girl to stay quiet so no one wakes up, removes slippers carefully, and prepares a garbage bag, showing consideration and planning.
Lies down thoughtful, sad, and unable to sleep but shows no proactive action.
Carefully climbs so he doesn’t wake his sisters, takes clothes and food to prepare for escape with Sahar, whispers to Sahar to keep plan secret and protect her.
Takes money from his father’s wallet without permission.
Shouts at his mother to stop her from sending his sister away and protects Sahar by holding her hand and closing the door to keep her safe.
Confronts his abusive mother despite being hit, showing concern and protectiveness for his sister.
Runs after Selim and Sahar trying to stop them despite being hit and shouted at by his mother, yelling Sahar's name with tears in his eyes.
Tries to break a wooden door in desperation as his mother shouts and hits him.
Runs away crying and enraged, showing emotional vulnerability.
Looks at Harout with surprise and listens to his story, engages briefly in conversation.
Does not respond harshly or dismissively to Harout’s odd behavior or cigarette despite bus driver’s intervention.
Mostly silent and introspective, showing no overt friendliness or warmth in this scene.
Sneaks on Harout’s destination and insists on getting off at the same stop.
Sits on the ferris wheel ride with tears in his eyes, showing emotional vulnerability and possibly longing for connection.

Lies quietly next to Rahil and Yonas, sharing a tender moment, showing closeness and affection.
